newsitem.title: USA: WHX strike could last several months - USW.
newsitem.headline: WHX strike could last several months - USW.

text.p: The United Steelworkers union is bracing itself for a protractive fight with WHX Corp and its current strike against the company, now in its eleventh day, could continue for several months, union officials said.
"We're going to keep this going as long as we have to until we feel we get what we deserve," Mickey Forte, president of Local 1187, told Reuters.
Some 4,500 steelworkers walked off the job October 1 after their former contract expired and negotiations failed to produce a new one. The strike has idled eight steel plants in three states.
Forte said pensions remain the major divisive issue. The union wants WHX to establish a defined benefit plan, which guarantees funding regardless of hours worked.
WHX currently has a defined contribution plan, which is funded based on age and hours worked and is cheaper to fund than a defined benefit plan.

A bankruptcy court ruling barred the company from offering a defined benefit plan until this year. WHX has maintained it cannot afford such a plan and needs its $406 million of cash-in-hand for debt and interest payments and capital expenditures.

"A defined benefit plan forces the company to put a lot of money up front and that's risky," company spokesman Gregg Warren said. "(Steel) is a cyclical business. It's hard to make those kinds of commitments when you don't know what will happen in the future."
Forte said WHX should put some of its cash-in-hand into a pension plan. "It would take $95 million of ($406 million) to fund the first three years of a defined benefit plan."
The strike has halted WHX's steel production but inventories that were built up prior to the strike will allow the company to ship product for 60-90 days, Forte said.
But he said striking workers are asking truck drivers not to take steel from the plants and some drivers have complied.

The company during negotiations offered to enhance its defined contribution plan. WHX said it would provide monthly benefits of $1,600 per month for workers with 44 years of service or more; $1,500 per month for service of 41-43 years; $1,400 per month for service of 36-40 years; $1,300 per month for service of 31-35 years; and $1,200 per month for service of 30 years or less.

But Forte said that proposal increases contributions only for employees over 50 years of age. Plus, the proposal is good only for the life of a contract, he said. "If we chose not to renew the contract, we would have to renegotiate the whole plan," he said.
Forte said union members also are upset because WHX is the only integrated steelmaker in the country that does not have a defined benefit plan, but Warren said such plans are a thing of the past.
"They may be the way in the steel industry, but their not the way in industry as a whole," he said. "Defined benefit plans are dinosaurs."
